Scheme 1 Highly efficient electrolytic reduction of nitrate to produce ammonia using Cu@Ni2P-NF Schottky heterojunction Li Min Sun Liping ⁎ Huo Lihua Zhao Hui ⁎ Key Laboratory of Functional Inorganic Material Chemistry, Ministry of Education, School of Chemistry and Materials Science, Heilongjiang University, Harbin 150080, PR China Key Laboratory of Functional Inorganic Material Chemistry, Ministry of Education, School of Chemistry and Materials Science, Heilongjiang University Harbin 150080 PR China Key Laboratory of Functional Inorganic Material Chemistry, Ministry of Education, School of Chemistry and Materials Science, Heilongjiang University, Harbin 150080, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Electrolytic reduction of nitrate to produce ammonia (NO3 -RR) is one of the very promising alternatives to the energy-consuming Haber-Bosch process. The catalytic activity of nitrate reduction can be effectively improved by tuning the electronic structure and interfacial electron transfer. In this work, Cu@Ni2P-NF metal- semiconductor heterostructure is designed to adjust the adsorption of H* while enhance the adsorption of NO3 - through schottky contacts. It is shown that the synergistic effects realized by the built-in electric field could effectively improve the NO3 -RR catalytic performance. In the electrolytic cell with 1 M KOH and 20 mM KNO3, the ammonia yield at –0.2 V (vs. RHE) reaches 0.374 mmol∙h−1∙cm−2, and the nitrate removal efficiency is up to 94.63% with a selectivity of 90.25%. The energy conversion is realized by applying a Zn-NO3 - battery with power density of 5.09 mW∙cm−2. This work demonstrates that the design of metal-semiconductor schottky heterojunction is an effective way to obtain novel electrocatalysts for NO3 -RR. Graphical Abstract Keywords Nitrate reduction reaction Schottky heterojunctions Nickel phosphide Copper Zn-NO3 - battery Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ammonia is an important raw material for the synthesis of fertilizers, pharmaceuticals, fuels and chemicals, and has a significant impact on food, energy and chemical production [1–4]. The main production method of ammonia is the Haber-Bosch process, which is highly energy-consuming and cause the emission of large amounts of greenhouse gases [5–7]. There is a need to find new alternatives that can produce ammonia in an energy efficient and clean manner. Nitrogen reduction (NRR) has received widespread attention due to its ability to produce ammonia at low temperatures. But the stable NN (941KJ∙mol−1) makes it extremely difficult to activate the N2 molecular, and the competing HER reaction further reduces the Faraday efficiency, selectivity and ammonia yield of NRR reaction [3,6,8,9]. NO3 - is widely present in surface and groundwater [10], mainly due to the deterioration of water quality from agricultural wastewater discharges [11]. Excessive absorption of NO3 - can reduce oxygen levels in the blood, leading to a potentially fatal disease commonly known as “methemoglobinemia”. More seriously, the absorbed NO3 - is easily converted to NO2 - in the body, increasing the risk of cancer and posing a threat to human health [12,13]. Therefore, the World Health Organization stipulates that the content of NO3 --N in drinking water should be ≤ 11.3 mg/L [14]. Thus, the conversion and removal of nitrate has attracted great attention [15,16]. NO3 - is difficult to be recovered and utilized directly, whereas it can be converted into recoverable high-value products such as NH3 or liquid ammonia [17,18]. The electrocatalytic conversion of NO3 - to NH3 (NO3 -RR) is reasonable from the point of view of reducing energy consumption, environmental stress and human health, and the method has received increasing attention [19–22]. Moreover, the energy required for NO3 - deoxygenation, i.e., the dissociation of NO is 204 KJ∙mol−1, which is quite low compared to the energy required for the dissociation of NN [23,24]. Hence, the NO3 -RR process is energy efficient compared to the Haber method. However, the electrocatalytic reduction of NO3 - to NH3 involves multiple reaction intermediates that require the transfer of eight electrons and nine protons (Eq. 1), which produces unwanted by-products such as NO2 - (Eq. 2), N2 (Eq. 3), etc.[25] In addition, HER as a competing reaction also affects the faraday efficiency and selectivity of NO3 -RR [26,27]. Consequently, it is necessary to screen catalyst materials with high ammonia selectivity in practical applications. (1) N O 3 − + 9 H + + 8 e − → N H 3 + 3 H 2 O (2) N O 3 − + 2 H + + 2 e − → N O 2 − + H 2 O (3) 2 N O 3 − + 12 H + + 10 e − → N 2 + 6 H 2 O Metals with unpaired d-electrons and/or d-band energies similar to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of NO3 -, such as Cu, Ag and Pt, are able to promote electron injection into the LUMO of NO3 -, thereby improving the kinetic properties of NO3 -RR [28–32]. It was reported that NO3 - had strong adsorption on Cu. xu et al. [33] designed CuPd/CN nanobridge electrocatalysts. It was found that the formed metal-support interactions in between CuPd and CN were able to modulate the surface adsorption/desorption behaviors of intermediate molecules, and the Cu was more conducive to the adsorption of NO3 - after accumulating a positive charge. Whereas the adsorption of hydrogen atoms by Cu was quite weak [34,35]. In this sense, the hydrogenation of NO3 - to form NO2 - was hindered, resulting in low ammonia selectivity on Cu catalyst. Transition metal phosphides (TMPs) such as Ni2P show attractive HER activity and stability [36]. In addition, Yao et al. [17] reported that Ni2P was favorable for the NO3-RR process due to its superhydrophilic surface and good metallic properties. Wei et al. [37] studied the NO3 -RR catalytic performance of Ni2P. They found that the saturation coverage of *H on Ni2P was much lower than some metals such as Ni or Pd, therefore benefited to the hydrogenation process in the nitrate reduction reaction [38]. The electronic interaction at the heterojunction interface can improve the reaction kinetics of NO3 -RR. Du et al. [39] designed Cu2O/CuO heterostructure catalysts that derived from mixed-valence double reticulated copper metal-organic frameworks. They reported that the d-band center of the active Cu site could be effectively tuned by the formation of heterojunction interface, and the reaction kinetics of NO3 -RR was then promoted. Recently, Wang et al. [40] found that HER performance could be effectively inhibited on Cu/Cu2O heterojunction material, and NH3 selectivity was improved. Hence, it would be reasonable to design a new type of heterostructure catalyst, which combines the good nitrate adsorption capacity of Cu with the ability of Ni2P to efficiently transfer and adsorb hydrogen, and effectively improves the catalytic activity of NO3 -RR by using the synergistic effect brought by the heterojunction. In this work, Cu@Ni2P-NF metal-semiconductor heterostructure is designed. The ammonia yield at −0.2 V (vs. RHE) reaches 0.374 mmol∙h−1∙cm−2, and the nitrate removal efficiency is up to 94.63% with a selectivity of 90.25%. We found the formation of schottky contact promoted the electron flow from Ni2P to metallic Cu. The formation of holes in Ni2P enhanced the strong adsorption of H*, and hindered the further formation/release of H2; whereas the enrichment of electrons in metallic Cu improved the adsorption of NO3 -. Therefore the synergistic effect of heterojunction formed by Cu metal and Ni2P semiconductor effectively improved the selectivity and ammonia yield through NO3 -RR process. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials All chemicals were used directly without further purification. Ni foam (thickness: 1.0 mm, porosity: ∼98%) was obtained from Kunshan Guangjiayuan New Material Co., Ltd (China). nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2∙6 H2O), copper sulfate (CuSO4), sodium hypophosphite monohydrate (NaH2PO2∙H2O), potassium nitrate (KNO3) were purchased from McLean Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd (China). Potassium hydroxide (KOH), hexamethylenetetramine (C6H12N4), sulfuric acid (H2SO4 98%), hydrochloric acid (HCl 36−38%), and absolute ethanol (CH3CH2OH) were obtained from Tianjin Kemio Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (China). Deionized water (18.2 MΩ cm) was used for the experiments. 2.2 Synthesis of Ni(OH)2-NF Ni(OH)2-NF was synthesized using hydrothermal method. Typically, a piece of nickel foam (NF, 1.0 cm×4.0 cm×0.1 cm) was sonicated with ethanol and 3 M HCl for 20 min, and rinsed with deionized water and ethanol to remove the oxide layer on the surface. The cleaned nickel foam was placed in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, to which 2 mmol of Ni(NO3)2∙6 H2O, 8.75 mmol of HMT and 35 mL of deionized water were added. The autoclave was then maintained at 120 °C for 6 h. The obtained Ni(OH)2-NF was washed several times with ethanol and deionized water and dried in air. 2.3 Preparation of Ni2P/NF 1 g of NaH2PO2∙H2O and a piece of Ni(OH)2-NF were placed seperatly in the upstream and downstream of the tube furnace, and heated at 260 °C for 1 h in Ar atmosphere. The resulting Ni2P-NF was washed several times with ethanol and deionized water and dried in N2. 2.4 Preparation of Cu@Ni2P-NF Cu@Ni2P-NF was synthesized by electrodeposition method using a three-electrode system on a CHI-760E electrochemical workstation. The prepared Ni2P-NF (1.0 cm×2.0 cm×0.1 cm) was used as the working electrode, Platinum foil as the counter electrode and saturated calomel electrode (SCE) as the reference electrode. The electrodeposition process was carried out in a mixed solution of 0.05 M H2SO4 containing 20 mM CuSO4 at −1.9 V (vs. Hg/HgCl2) for 300 s. The deposited area was 1.0 cm×1.0 cm. The obtained Cu@Ni2P-NF was cleaned with ethanol and deionized water for several times. As comparison, The Cu-NF was prepared in the same conditions except that nickel foam (NF) was used as the working electrode for electrodeposition. 2.5 Characterizations The crystal structures of the synthesized samples were characterized using X-ray diffractometer (XRD; Bruker AXS D8, Cu Kα). The microstructures of the synthesized samples were investigated using scanning electron microscopy (SEM; SUPRA-55), transmission electron microscopy (TEM; JEOL-JEM-2100), and high-resolution TEM images (HRTEM). The chemical state and surface properties of the synthesized samples were analyzed using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; Thermo ESCALAB 250, Al-K rays) and all peaks were corrected with C1s. The light absorption properties of the synthesized samples were analyzed using UV–vis absorption spectroscopy (UV–vis, PerkinElmer Lambda-900). The work function and valence band structure of the synthesized samples were analyzed using ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy (UPS, Kratos Axis Supra TM). The synthesized samples were used directly for XRD, SEM, XPS and UPS measurements without further processing. The electrocatalytic activity of Cu@Ni2P-NF was evaluated with electrochemical workstation (CHI 760E). The details of measuring procedures could be found in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Morphological and structural characterization The synthesis procedure of Cu@Ni2P-NF heterostructure material was presented in Scheme 1. First, Ni(OH)2-NF was synthesized through hydrothermal method. The XRD patterns of Ni(OH)2-NF matches well with the standard card (JCPDS: 14–0117) (Figure S1a). The SEM image shows the ultra-thin nanosheet morphology of Ni(OH)2 on NF (Figure S1b). Fig. 1 a shows the XRD patterns of Cu@Ni2P-NF. The diffraction peaks located at 40.9°, 44.7°, 47.4°, 54.3° and 54.9° correspond to the (111), (201), (210), (300) and (211) crystal planes of Ni2P (JCPDS: 03–0953). The diffraction peaks located at 44.6°, 51.9° and 76.4° belong to the (111), (200) and (220) crystal planes of metal nickel (JCPDS: 04–0850) that coming from the Ni foam substrate. The diffraction peaks at 43.4°, 50.6° and 74.3° correspond to (111), (200) and (220) crystal planes of copper (JCPDS: 04–0836). The XRD results prove the successful preparation of Cu@Ni2P-NF. As a control, Cu-NF and Ni2P-NF are also prepared according to the above procedures. The XRD patterns shown in Figure S2 indicate the successful synthesis of these two materials. From the corresponding SEM images, it is observed that Ni2P-NF retains the ultra-thin nanosheet morphology of Ni(OH)2-NF precursor after low-temperature phosphating (Figure S3a). The SEM image of Cu-NF shows a dendritic structure (Fig. S3b). For Cu@Ni2P-NF, the SEM image clearly shows the morphology of dendritic Cu on Ni2P nanosheets (Fig. 1 b), indicating the formation of heterostructure material. The details of the heterostructure are further observed by TEM (Fig. 1 c). Furthermore, several lattice fringe spacing of 0.208 nm and 0.228 nm could be observed from the HRTEM (Fig. 1 d), which belong to the (111) plane of Cu and (111) plane of Ni2P respectively. In addition, the HAADF-STEM and element mapping show that Cu elements are distributed in copper dendrites, and Ni, P and O elements are evenly distributed on Ni2P-NF (Fig. 1 e-i). These results indicate that Cu@Ni2P-NF catalyst with heterostructure has been successfully prepared. 3.2 Electronic structure of Cu@Ni2P-NF The chemical valence of each element in Cu@Ni2P-NF was analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The XPS survey spectrum confirms the presence of Cu, Ni, P and O elements in Cu@Ni2P-NF (Figure S4). The XPS spectrum of Ni 2p shows two spin-orbit doublets and two shakeup satellites ( Fig. 2 a). The binding energies (BEs) at 856.11 eV and 873.98 eV correspond to Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2, and the BEs at 861.70 eV and 879.88 eV belong to the shakeup satellites (sat.), respectively [41]. In the XPS spectrum of P 2p (Fig. 2 b), the peak with BEs at 129.55 eV corresponds to P 2p1/2 in Ni2P, while the P-O bond at 133.86 eV is attributed to the formation of phosphate oxide when the material is in contact with air [41]. The Cu 2p XPS spectrum (Fig. 2 c) shows two main peaks at 932.05 eV and 951.91 eV, corresponding to Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 of Cu0, respectively. The additional peaks at 933.76 eV, 953.84 eV, 943.11 eV and 962.43 eV belong to Cu2+ and satellite peaks, respectively. The presents of Cu2+ maybe due to the surface oxidation of Cu when the material is exposed in air [42]. As comparison, the XPS spectra of Cu-NF and Ni2P-NF are collected, and the analysis results are presented in Table S1 and Table S2. Remarkably, compared with Ni2P-NF，the Ni 2p and P 2p peaks of Cu@Ni2P-NF shift positively 0.16 eV and 0.1 eV towards the high binding energy direction, respectively. While compared with Cu-NF, the Cu 2p peak of Cu@Ni2P-NF shifts negatively 0.26 eV. These results show that there exists a strong electronic interaction between Cu and Ni2P in the Cu@Ni2P-NF heterostructure material, and electrons flow from Ni2P to Cu due to the formation of schottky contact. The energy band structure and schottky contact of Cu@Ni2P-NF are further studied by several spectroscopic techniques. From the UV photoelectron spectrum (UPS), it is observed that the work function of Cu@Ni2P-NF (4.48 eV) is in between Ni2P-NF (4.29 eV) and Cu-NF (4.46 eV) ( Figures S5a -c), proving the formation of schottky heterojunction in Cu@Ni2P-NF. Fig. 3 a shows the UV absorption spectrum of Ni2P-NF. The corresponding Tauc plot is presented in Fig. 3 b. The band gap energy (Eg) obtained from the plot is 3.12 eV. The valence band value (EV) of Ni2P-NF is obtained from the UPS valence band spectrum, and it is 2.96 eV (Fig. 3 c). Accordingly, the conduction band value (EC) of Ni2P is −0.16 eV. Furthermore, it can be seen from Figure S6 that the slope of M-S curve is positive, indicating that Ni2P is an n-type semiconductor [43]. According to the above results and discussions, the energy band diagrams of metal copper and Ni2P-NF before and after the formation of Mott Schottky contact were proposed (Fig. 3 d). As mentioned earlier, the work function of metal Cu is greater than that of n-type semiconductor Ni2P. When the two materials form a close contact, electrons will transfer from Ni2P to Cu until the fermi level reaches equilibrium. In this sense, some holes will form and Ni2P is positively charged, while Cu will be negatively charged after obtaining electrons. A space charge region will then be produced in Ni2P semiconductor, and the generated internal electric field points from Ni2P to Cu. The electron concentration in the space charge region is lower than that in the semiconductor, so the energy band of the semiconductor bends upwards along the electric field line. A Schottky barrier（ϕSB) is formed due to the potential difference between the surface and the interior of semiconductor, which prevents the electrons on Cu flowing back to Ni2P and improve the charge separation efficiency [44]. When the catalytic reaction occurs, the electrons in the valence band of Ni2P are continuously excited and corresponding holes are generated. The holes will adsorb protons from water to form adsorbed hydrogen (H*), while Cu has good adsorption capacity for NO3 -, thereby the combination of Cu and Ni2P is supposed to promote the hydrogenation process in NO3 -RR and release NH3. 3.3 Electrocatalytic activity of NO3 -RR In order to explore the effects of Schottky heterostructure on nitrate reduction performance, the electrochemical performance of Cu@Ni2P-NF was evaluated in 1 M KOH using a three electrode system. The LSV curves of Cu@Ni2P-NF and Ni2P-NF are comparably shown in Fig. 4 a. In the electrolyte containing 20 mM KNO3, both the current density of Cu@Ni2P-NF and Ni2P-NF increased in the potential range of 0.3 to −0.5 V (vs. RHE). Compared with Ni2P-NF, the current density of Cu@Ni2P-NF increased much more significantly. While in the electrolyte without nitrate, the current density of Cu@Ni2P-NF decreased. It indicates that HER process is inhibited on Cu@Ni2P-NF electrode, which helps to promote NO3 -RR process [45]. Meanwhile, compared with Cu-NF, the current density of Cu@Ni2P-NF was also significantly increased in the electrolyte containing 20 mM KNO3. The above results indicate that Cu@Ni2P-NF has high catalytic performance for NO3 -RR. According to the results of LSV, the electrolytic reaction was carried out by chronoamperometry in the potential range of 0.0∼-0.4 V (vs. RHE). The UV absorbance of products was measured using UV–visible spectrophotometry and the corresponding UV absorption spectra are presented in Figure S10a -c. The product concentration was calculated based on the standard curve (Figure S7 -9). It is observed the NH4 + yield of Cu@Ni2P-NF increases with the applied potential, and reaches the highest value of 0.414 mmol∙h−1∙cm−2 at −0.4 V (vs. RHE) ( Fig. 4 b). In addition, the NH4 + yield of Cu@Ni2P-NF is much higher than that of Ni2P-NF and Cu-NF at given potentials. The faraday efficiency (FE) of Cu@Ni2P-NF shows a "volcanic curve", with the highest FE value of 80.12% at −0.2 V (vs. RHE). This result is due to the competitive HER reaction, which becomes more serious at high over-potential. In this case, the active hydrogen species (H*) tend to convert to hydrogen molecules, resulting in the decrease of FE of NO3 -RR [46]. Generally the conversion of NO3 - to NO2 - is considered as the rate determining step in the NO3 -RR process [47,48]. In this sense, the yields of NO2 - in the electrolyte solution was measured by UV absorption spectra (Figure S11a -c). It is observed that Ni2P-NF shows the smallest NO2 - yields at each given potential (Fig. 4 c). Considering that the FE of Ni2P-NF is 68.14%, and the conversion rate of NO3 - is only 22.72% (Figure S12), it is reasonable that the low NO3 - conversion rate leads to low NO2 - yields. This result indicates that Ni2P-NF is not a good electrocatalyst for NO3 -RR process. It should be noted that the NO2 - yields on Cu-NF is the highest among the studied three materials, whereas there is very little NO2 - remaining in the electrolyte with Cu@Ni2P-NF electrode. This result suggests that the NO2 - produced by Cu could be further reduced to NH3 by Ni2P on Cu@Ni2P-NF electrode. In order to confirm this hypothesis, electrolytic tests were further conducted in 1 M KOH containing 20 mM KNO2 to evaluate the reduction ability of different catalysts to convert NO2 - to ammonia. As shown in Fig. 4 d, Cu@Ni2P-NF has the highest NO2 - conversion rate and NH4 + yield, indicating that Cu@Ni2P-NF has the best catalytic activity for hydrogenation reduction of NO2 -. Meanwhile, the performance of Ni2P-NF is much superior to that of Cu-NF, indicating that Ni2P-NF has good NO2 - conversion and reduction ability. Cu-CF shows the least activity for NO2 - reduction reaction. The above results clearly show the synergetic contributions of Cu and Ni2P in Cu@Ni2P-NF, which ensure the promising NO3 -RR performance of the heterostructure catalysts. In order to study the effect of NO3 - concentration on the catalytic activity of Cu@Ni2P-NF, linear sweep test (LSV) was carried out in 1 M KOH electrolyte with different concentrations of KNO3 ( Figure S13a ). It is observed the NH4 + yield increases with the increase of KNO3 concentration, but the Faraday efficiency reaches the highest value in the electrolyte containing 20 mM KNO3 (Figure S13b ). Furthermore, LSV was also carried out to study the effects of pH on the catalytic performance (Figure S14). It is found the catalytic activity of Cu@Ni2P-NF in 1 M KOH and 20 mM KNO3 electrolytes is significantly better than that measured in 1 M Na2SO4 and 20 mM KNO3. Hence, subsequent tests were conducted in an electrolyte containing 20 mM KNO3 and 1 M KOH at −0.2 V (vs. RHE). The catalytic activities of several catalysts were comparably evaluated by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy. The Nyquist plots showed that the EIS semicircle was the smallest for Cu@Ni2P-NF (Fig. 4 e), indicating that Cu@Ni2P-NF has the best electron transfer performance. As shown in Fig. 4 f, the Tafel slope of Cu@Ni2P-NF is 121.84 mV∙dec−1, which is smaller than Ni2P-NF (155.34 mV∙dec−1) and Cu-NF (126.07 mV∙dec−1). It is proved that the NO3 -RR kinetics of Cu@Ni2P-NF is the fastest. Besides, the electrochemical active surface areas of these materials were evaluated in the non-Faraday region (Figure S15a -d). The double layer capacitance (Cdl) value of Cu@Ni2P-NF is 12.45 mF∙cm−2, which is 1.6 times and 6.2 times higher than Ni2P-NF (8.55 mF∙cm−2) and Cu-NF (1.95 mF∙cm−2), respectively. The Cu@Ni2P-NF heterostructure shows the highest active specific surface area, which may improve the catalytic activity of NO3 -RR. Additionally, in order to verify the intrinsic activity of Cu@Ni2P-NF, the changes of NO3 -, NO2 - and NH4 + were recorded at −0.2 v within 2 h of cumulative electrolysis (vs. RHE). With the accumulation of time, the concentration of NO3 - decreased rapidly and almost completely exhausted after 120 min. Conversely, the concentration of NH4 + gradually increased within 2 h. The concentration of NO2 - increased at the beginning 40 min, and then decreased to a low concentration with the accumulation of reaction time ( Fig. 5 a and Figure S16). This phenomenon indicates that NO2 - generated during the reaction may be re-adsorbed on the catalyst and further converted to ammonia [24]. A pseudo-first-order kinetics model ( d c d t = − k C , where C is the concentration of NO3 - and t is the reaction time) was used to analyze the kinetic properties of different catalysts [49]. Fig. 5 b shows the variation curve of ln(C/C0) over time for different catalysts in the 2 h electrolysis reaction. The obtained k value of Cu@Ni2P-NF is 21.2×10−3 min−1, which is 3.4 times (6.2×10−3 min−1) and 2.2 times (9.7×10−3 min−1) higher than Ni2P-NF and Cu-NF, respectively. The results show that the catalyst has high kinetic properties, which is consistent with the electrochemical results. The removal efficiency of NO3 - in Cu@Ni2P-NF reached 94.63% after 2 h electrolysis, which was higher than that of Ni2P-NF (53.06%) and Cu-NF (77.28%). Meanwhile, Cu@Ni2P-NF shows high ammonia selectivity (90.25%), which is also superior to Ni2P-NF (53.72%) and Cu-NF (30.32%) (Fig. 5 c). This result also indicates that although the removal efficiency of NO3 - on Cu-NF is higher than that of Ni2P-NF, the slow hydrogenation of accumulated NO2 - on the surface of Cu leads to its low ammonia selectivity. In order to eliminate the possible fake results, some control experiments were carried out and the results are shown in Figure S17. It is found ammonia was detected only in the electrolyte containing KNO3, eliminating the influence of other possible nitrogen-containing pollutants. Simultaneously, the stability of Cu@Ni2P-NF was evaluated by cyclic electrolysis test. As shown in Fig. 5 e, the Faraday efficiency and ammonia yield remain stable within 12 cyclic electrolysis measurements. Meanwhile, the average ammonia production rate within the 12 cyclic measurements is 0.340. And the calculated average error value is 2.92%. This result proves the good reliability of the electrolysis measurements. In addition for the prolonged 6 h electrolysis measurement, although the catalytic current of Cu@Ni2P-NF decreased during the electrolysis process, it can be recovered after refreshing the electrolyte each hour (Fig. 5 f). The attenuation of the catalytic current should be attributed to the fast consumption of nitrate during the NO3 -RR reaction. The above results confirm that Cu@Ni2P-NF has good stability. The XRD pattern shows that the crystal phase of the catalyst does not change after long-term electrochemical measurements (Figure S18). The TEM results also prove that the heterostructure remain stable (Figure S19a -g). From the XPS spectra (Figure S20a -d), it is observed the Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 peaks of Cu2+ have increased, indicating that the content of copper in the divalent oxidation state has increased. This may be due to the surface oxidation caused by the complete contact between the catalyst and the electrolyte during the reaction. Based on the above discussions, it is believed that the phase and morphology of the catalyst are well preserved. Cu@Ni2P-NF has good stability in the process of nitrate reduction. Finally, the ammonia yield of Cu@Ni2P-NF is superior than most reported NO3 -RR catalysts (Fig. 5 d, Table S3). 3.4 Reaction mechanisms The main competitive reaction during nitrate reduction is HER process. Therefore, when selecting catalysts, it is necessary to avoid selecting HER catalysts with excellent performance and rapid hydrolysis ability [23]. However, H* released by water reduction (Volmer mechanism) can also continue to catalyze the reduction of nitrate to ammonia [50]. If HER performance is completely inhibited, no protons are involved in the hydrogenation of NO3 -RR and ammonia cannot be further synthesized. Therefore, we need to choose catalysts with certain HER performance that can efficiently synthesize ammonia while providing protons. When the catalytic reaction occurs, the protons originate from the hydrolysis process of H2O [51], the reaction is as follows: H 2 O + e − → O H − + H a d s ( Volmer ) H a d s + H 2 O + e − → O H − + H 2 ( H e y r o v s k y ) o r 2 H a d s → H 2 ( T a f e l ) The Hads formed by hydrolysis first adsorb on the surface of the catalyst, and then form hydrogen molecules that to be released into air. If the HER performance of the catalyst is excellent, the surface coverage of Hads is oversaturated, and hydrogen molecules will continue to be released. In this sense, the required protons for NO3 -RR will be consumed, while the active center of the reaction is occupied by HER. Although Ni2P has good HER performance, its H* saturation coverage is much lower than that of metals such as Pd and Ni. In this sense, the hydrogenation ability of Ni2P can be enhanced [52]. Furthermore, the electron re-distribution on the heterostructure catalysts can alter the adsorption of H, thereby affect the hydrogen evolution performance [53]. As shown in Figure S21, the Tafel slope of Cu-NF during HER process is 122.6 mV∙dec−1, proving that the rate determining step on Cu is the Volmer step [54]. While the Tafel slope of Ni2P-NF and Cu@Ni2P-NF are 96.1 mV∙dec−1 and 99.9 mV∙dec−1, indicating the HER process may follow the Heyrovsk step [54]. This result proves that the hydrogen adsorption property can be effectively adjusted by the formation of Cu@Ni2P-NF heterojunction. Compared to Cu-NF, the hydrogen adsorption ability is enhanced on Cu@Ni2P-NF. Therefore the hydrogenate ability is promoted and the NO3 -RR performance is improved on Cu@Ni2P-NF. Based on the above discussions, the electrocatalytic reduction mechanism of NO3 - on Cu@Ni2P-NF heterojunction is schematically proposed in Fig. 6. Under the action of the built-in electric field, Ni2P loses electrons and forms holes, which enhances the adsorbing of Hads from the hydrolysis process on catalyst surface. At the same time, the accumulated electrons on Cu will back donate to the antibonding orbital of adsorbed NO3 -. In this sense, the synergistic effects achieved by the formation of heterogeneous structures can effectively improve the catalytic activity of nitrate reduction in the synthesis of ammonia. 3.5 Zn-NO3 - battery applications Considering that Cu@Ni2P-NF shows excellent catalytic activity for NO3 -RR, it would be interesting to explore the application of nitrate ion battery by using the current generated in the eight-electron process of nitric acid reduction. Zn-NO3 - battery was then assembled with Cu@Ni2P-NF catalyst as positive electrode and zinc flake as negative electrode. As shown in Fig. 7 a, this Zn-NO3 - battery shows an open-circuit voltage of 0.90 V, which is close to the theoretical value of 1.12 V. The discharge test of Cu@Ni2P-NF based Zn-NO3 - battery was carried out in 1 M KOH and 0.5 M KNO3. The maximum power density of the battery reached 5.09 mW∙cm−2 (Fig. 7 b), which was higher than the performance of Ni2P-NF-based (2.825 mW∙cm−2) and Cu-NF-based Zn-NO3 - batteries (3.192 mW∙cm−2) (Figure S22). Concurrently, discharge tests were carried out in electrolytes containing different amounts of nitrate (Figure S23). The power density was found to increase with the NO3 - concentration, and reached stable value when the NO3 - concentration was 0.5 M. Therefore, the subsequent tests were carried out in 1 M KOH and 0.5 M KNO3. When the Zn-NO3 - battery was discharged at different current densities, a ladder-shaped profile of voltage with stable discharge plateaus is observed (Fig. 7 c), which suggested the excellent electrochemical kinetics of Cu@Ni2P-NF based Zn-NO3 - battery. The long-term discharge test was further carried out at a current density of 15 mA∙cm−2. As shown in Fig. 7 d, the power density decreased from 5.09 mW∙cm−2 to 4.6 mW∙cm−2 due to the consumption of NO3 - during the reaction. Meanwhile, the consumption of NO3 - increased with the increase of current density, and the ammonia yield at the maximum current density can reach 45 μmol∙h−1∙cm−2 (Fig. 7 e), which is better than most reported catalysts (Fig. 7 f, Table S4). In addition, three Zn-NO3 - battery connected in series could continuously power the “HLJU” pattern that composed by 36 light–emitting diodes in parallel for 6 h (inset of Fig. 4 d, Figure S24 and S25). This result proves that the Cu@Ni2P-NF-based Zn-NO3 - battery has good stability and practicability. 4 Conclusion Cu@Ni2P-NF heterostructure catalyst was successfully prepared and the synergistic effects of schottky heterojunction on electrocatalytic activity were discussed in this study. The built-in electric field formed at the heterojunction interface results in a re-distribution of electrons in Cu@Ni2P-NF. The holes produced in Ni2P enhanced the adsorption of Hads, and electrons accumulated on Cu promoted the adsorption of NO3 -. Therefore the faraday efficiency of NO3 -RR reached the highest value of 80.12% at −0.2 V (vs. RHE), and the NH4 + yield was 0.374 mmol∙h−1∙cm−2. In addition, a Zn-NO3 - battery with Cu@Ni2P-NF cathode was assembled to realize the co-producing of electric power and value-added products. In summary, the synergy contribution of metal semiconductor heterojunction proposed in this study enriches the design and application of catalysts in nitrate reduction reaction. coredata.dc:description: Electrolytic reduction of nitrate to produce ammonia (NO3 -RR) is one of the very promising alternatives to the energy-consuming Haber-Bosch process. The catalytic activity of nitrate reduction can be effectively improved by tuning the electronic structure and interfacial electron transfer. In this work, Cu@Ni2P-NF metal- semiconductor heterostructure is designed to adjust the adsorption of H* while enhance the adsorption of NO3 - through schottky contacts. It is shown that the synergistic effects realized by the built-in electric field could effectively improve the NO3 -RR catalytic performance. In the electrolytic cell with 1 M KOH and 20 mM KNO3, the ammonia yield at –0.2 V (vs. RHE) reaches 0.374 mmol∙h−1∙cm−2, and the nitrate removal efficiency is up to 94.63% with a selectivity of 90.25%. The energy conversion is realized by applying a Zn-NO3 - battery with power density of 5.09 mW∙cm−2. This work demonstrates that the design of metal-semiconductor schottky heterojunction is an effective way to obtain novel electrocatalysts for NO3 -RR.
coredata.dc:title: Highly efficient electrolytic reduction of nitrate to produce ammonia using Cu@Ni2P-NF Schottky heterojunction
